awd_titl_txt: Long Wavelength Array (LWA) Observations of Meteor Trail Radio Emission: A Laboratory for Terrestrial Plasma Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses the relatively recently observed phenomenon of radio wave emission by meteor trails. Ionized meteor trails have long been providing temperature and wind information in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere by reflecting radio signals. However, the mechanism for radio wave emission by ablating meteors is  largely unknown. Knowledge of meteor emissions is highly pertinent to ongoing searches for extraterrestrial objects on similar time scales (seconds to minutes). This project will use radio and video measurements to explore the structure, time evolution, and formation mechanism of the meteor radio emissions.  

The areas near the PI's telescope arrays are instrumented with video cameras. This suite of radio and video measurements will be used to triangulate the trajectories of the meteors, and take detailed images to measure the trail's expansion. The telescopes are a community resource that facilitates astronomical research, and involve undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students at a university serving a large minority population. The telescope arrays are situated within the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge, and engage the public through a dedicated exhibit at the wildlife visitor center.

por.por_cntn:
Every second, millions of meteoroids traveling between 11-76 km/s collide with Earth's upper atmosphere, leaving behind trails of plasma at altitudes between 60 and 130 km. Most meteoroids disintegrate completely in the atmosphere, but occasionally some will make it to the ground as meteorites. Meteors come in a large variety of compositions and orbits. These factors determine the altitudes at which the meteors disintigrate.

Recently it was discovered that larger meteors can produce strong radio emission between 10 and 60 MHz. This emission is of considerable interest as it provides a new way to probe the conditions of the upper atmosphere, and may reveal valuable insights about meteors themselves. We have been using radio observations with the Long Wavelength Array (LWA) in New Mexico between 4 and 88 MHz, together with more traditional observations with wide-field optical cameras, to study both the meteors.  An outstanding question is the emission mechanism of the radio emission produced by these meteor radio afterglows (MRAs).  Through this award we discovered an association between the MRAs and long-lived persistent optical emission that can linger for minutes following a meteor (so called persistent trains). This association suggests a common origin in chemical reactions in the upper atmosphere energized by meteors. 

In the accompanying figure we show the low frequency image of a meteor radio afterglow taken using the Owens Valley Radio Observatory Long Wavelength Array in California during the Perseid meteor shower. This meteor stretches over 10 degrees in the sky, twenty times the angular diameter of the full moon.  Four frequencies are shown  between 31 and 47 MHz, and the angular resolution for each is  shown by the ellipse in the lower left corner.  One can see that the meteor is brightest at the lowest frequency where it reaches a  peak flux density of 1400 Jy/beam.  There is also considerable  structure along the trail which also varies as a function of frequency.  At the highest frequency the emission appears more uniform along much of the trail compared to lower frequencies that fade more rapidly.  This information could provide clues to the nature of the emission mechanism for MRAs, which is not yet understood.

While MRAs can occur at any time of year, they are more frequent during meteor showers.  We continue to study these interesting objects with simultaneous radio and optical observations.  At the same time, we are finding a wealth of information from many years of LWA observations that provide monitoring of the entire visible hemisphere. A feature of the Long Wavelength Array stations is that they can produce images of the sky above them in real-time.  These images are used to look for transient sources such as meteors and gamma-ray bursts, and can be used to monitor the radio frequency interference environment at the station.  You can watch LWA-TV either from LWA1 or from LWA-SV station from this web page: http://www.phys.unm.edu/~lwa/lwatv.html.

This work supported the PhD research for Savin Varghese, and has also involved several other graduate and undergraduate students.  Results were published in refereed journals and presented at conferences.
